resource.chars:
Plate I

     Structure of the <u>Animal of Orbitolite</u>

Fig.
1. Entire Animal, from a small and simple disk, the shell having been
removed by maceration in acid; in the <s>outer</s> peripheral portion, the
segments of sarcode are wanting, and the structureless
residuum of the shell is alone seen. Magnified 40 diam.
2. Appearance of a portion of Sarcode, <s>more</s> highly magni-
fied;- 180 diam.
3. Portion of the body of one of the more complex forms (re-
sembling Fig. 4) in which the sarcode has broken-up into
little <s>spherules</s> spheres (gemmules?); <u>a,a,</u>, superficial cells; <u>b,b</u>, annular
band;- 180 diam.
4. Portion of the body of one of the more complex forms,
as seen in <u>vertical</u> section;-<u>aa</u>, <u>a'a'</u>, upper and
lower rows of superficial cells, each cell connected, at its two
extremities, with the annular bands <u>bb</u> and <u>b'b'</u> of
<u>two</u> zones; from <s>the lower part</s> of these annular bands
spring the columnar segments <u>cc</u>, <u>c'c'</u>, those of the same
